knowledge: Influenza Influenza The flu vaccine is an annual vaccine that protects against influenza viruses. It is the most effective way to prevent the flu. The vaccine is made from inactivated or weakened viruses that are not infectious. The vaccine works by triggering the body's immune system to produce antibodies that can recognize and fight the flu virus if you are exposed to it. The effectiveness of the flu vaccine varies from year to year and depends on the match between the vaccine and the circulating flu strains. Overall, the vaccine is about 40-60% effective in preventing the flu. However, even if you do get the flu after getting vaccinated, the vaccine can still reduce the severity of your symptoms. Influenza Influenza

The initial symptoms are usually fever, chills, headaches, muscle pain, and weakness. These may be accompanied by respiratory symptoms such as a dry cough, sore throat, and runny or stuffy nose. Yes, influenza can lead to pneumonia and other serious complications, especially in young children, the elderly, and people with weakened immune systems.
